instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_PWM: What is LCD_BKLT_PWM? LCD_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message:
Okay I made this topic a few weeks ago and I fixed the backlight and sent it out. The customer has sent this back saying the backlight will only turn on after like 10 or times of turning the machine on and off. I have the machine back and there is no backlight and I can see when I flash a light on the screen.

This was the previous topic I created [url]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/12250-solved-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-backlight-no-feedback-continuity[/url]

The backlight voltage from LCD connector shows from 7.49v to 8.36v. In diode mode Pin 2 of <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> and <CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR> show 0.599v.

To fix this board I scratched a little next to A5 feedback ball put some solder there and ran a wire to Pin 2 of <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>.

Should I try putting a new <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> on the board?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: If <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> was not replaced there is probably corrosion under it. Replace and make sure feedback trace is good.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: Tell me you didn't reuse the original <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. :)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: Intermittent back light is most likely the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>.... Hopefully you replaced it and did'nt reuse the old one like Louis said.  If you did replace, put a new one on and see if it fixes as it could have been a defective chip right from the reel.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message:
I replaced the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> after the liquid damage with a new one.
I just replaced it again and I can see it is soldered correctly and the feedback ball looks good.
Before I put the chip on there was continuity from the feedback pad to its traces that I scratched so I just put the new <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> on the board and I ran a wire from the trace of the A5 fb ball to Pin 2 of <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>. When I plug it in and measure pins 3/4 of LCD Connector I still get 8.35 and diode output is 0.591v.

Also, <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> on its probe point measured around 2.78v.

Update: I believe the issue here is <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>. I checked the voltage on it and it was showing around 0.14v to 0.80v.
I then checked the resistance with no power and it showed around 1 Mega ohm so I replaced <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>/<CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR>. Now it is showing 0v so I ran a wire from <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>(<RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR>) to <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>(<RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>/<CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR>) then both of them showed 0v and in diode mode I get a 0v drop to ground on Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>.

New measurements:
Diode mode (<DIODE>D9701</DIODE>) - 0.52v
<RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>(<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>) - 0v
Voltage mode Pins 3/4 LCD connector - 0v
L9701 (1/2) - 0v
<CHIP>U9000</CHIP>(Pin 1) - 3.21v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message:
Your new measurements without LCD connected? LCD must be connected!
Check for resistance to GND on <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message:
Yes. my new measurements were with LCD connected and screen open which is also how I got 3.2v on Pin 1 of the <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> chip.

Resistance to ground on <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> shows around 0.5ohms

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: well .5 is too low of course.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: How else can I fix this? I had already replaced <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR> from a donor. Could the <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Chip be pulling this down or the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> again?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: Is there signs of liquid near the PCH? The <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> is 2 bucks. Its worth a try as a diagnosis step. I doubt the laptop would boot if the PCH was screwed up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message:
There doesn't look to be liquid damage by the pch.
I removed the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and the short was still there was so I removed <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR> and the short was gone. I will put a new <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and replace those and see if that works.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: What side of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> is the short on now or was <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR> shorted?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message:
I'm not sure which component was causing the short but before I removed them there was a short to ground on both sides of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR>. Now there is no short. 
With the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>/<CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR> removed from the board Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> shows 0L in diode mode and Pin 2 shows 0.55v in diode mode.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: What is the voltage on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>? I believe the PCH generates that signal, If it is missing, my guess would be a bad or shorted PCH. Did you ultrasonic the board? If there is corrosion under the PCH that could explain this. When you measure voltage, use the probe point on the board and see what you get. But before jumping to the PCH, double check the entire board and see if there are any signs of damage such as burned or red probe points.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message:
Okay so I put another new <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and replaced <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>/<CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR>. I plugged in the screen and measured <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> and it was back at 3.24v but I still had 0v on Backlight output.
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> was 0v which is why I figure there is no voltage on backlight output. <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> measured 0.54v in diode mode.

<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> weren't measuring the proper resistance so I just replaced both of them but I still get 0v on <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and on Pins 3/4 LCD connector.

The probe point (Probe 957) that goes to <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> was barely visible so I tried to add some solder to it and hopefully bring it back but now it's completely gone. Is that probe point critical to where I need to run a wire for it?

Resistance to GND - <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> - 100k ohms

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCD_BKLT_PWR</SIGNAL> Present and what is the voltage?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sent back - no backlight again
threads.message:
There was no voltage on any pins of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> and there was voltage on Pins 2/5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> so I checked the fuse and it was blown. I replaced the fuse and now the backlight is working. 

Thanks for help guys.
